thread.title: New ANZ chief Shayne Elliott defends Asia strategy

author: Jeff Whalley
title: New ANZ chief Shayne Elliott defends Asia strategy
text:
ANZ chairman David Gonski and new chief executive Shayne Elliott have launched a robust defence of the bank’s push into Asia after the man who drove the strategy announced his retirement.
Mike Smith will quit after eight years at the helm to be replaced by Mr Elliott, the lender’s chief financial officer, at the end of this year.
Acknowledging changes would be made to the allocation of resources in Asia under his leadership, Mr Elliott said it was still the right place to be for the nation’s third-biggest bank.
And he said the Asia strategy is what attracted him to ANZ.
“The opportunity remains valid, but the way we operate has to change,” he said yesterday, admitting some of the bank’s tactics around capital allocation would be adapted.
Mr Elliott said the bank had gone to the board and examined whether the Asia strategy was correct, particularly as it was impacted by the global financial crisis.
“The analysis said, ‘yes, you would’. But I think it’s fair to say that if you knew then what you know now, maybe you’d have done it slightly differently.
Outgoing ANZ chief Mike Smith. Picture: Hollie Adams Source: News Corp Australia
“We’re going to have to continue to tweak and reassess where and how we deploy our capital, but that’s going to be my job.
“Does that mean we have to increase investment? It is about ensuring it is in the right places.”
Mr Elliott said he was not daunted by the volatility out of Asia that has driven a wild ride on local share markets.
“Asia certainly has been volatile ... but we are in for the long term,” he said.
“We think it is better to be there and be on the front foot rather than reading about it in the newspaper.”
Mr Gonski said the lender’s super-regional strategy was “not really understood” by many and was about Australia’s links into Asia rather than simply “investing in China”.
Under Mr Gonski, the ANZ board has been undertaking a very public international search for a successor to the long-serving Mr Smith, who pivoted the bank towards ­engaging the growing Asian ­financial services sector.
New Zealand-born Mr ­Elliott, 51, who boasts more than 30 years’ banking experience and joined ANZ six years ago, will succeed Mr Smith in January. He will be the first internal candidate promoted to the top job in 23 years.
Mr Gonski said Mr Elliott was the best candidate, particularly due to his vision for ANZ’s future.
“When we were in Silicon Valley (for an executive visit), I watched carefully how his mind works and how he analyses things. I have to say we have to turn these things to our advantage.”
The UK-born Mr Smith — who was renowned for his blunt assessments of Australian politics — said it was the role of CEOs to speak out.
“I sometimes think business leaders should call out problems, particularly when there is bad policy around ... you can’t moan about it if you haven’t said anything about it,” he said. “With me you get what you see, I’ve always been forthright in my views.”
As for Mr Elliott? He admitted he had “big shoes to fill”.
